elements.text: PART ONE
1. Ancient Egypt. Around 1400 BC.
In the deserts outside Thebes, the wind whistles, blowing sand. YANIS, a
mercenary chieftain, coughs and spits in the dust. He’s big, loud and he
has a permanent bad temper.
Damn this. Where is he?
Another voice speaks - HOREMSHEP (High Priest of Horus and leader of the Council of Priests in Thebes), though he’s not identified as such yet and the wind disguises his voice.
Yanis.
Finally. I thought you had got lost in the sandstorm.
Not this close to Thebes. YANIS A temple-rat like you could get lost in his own tunic. If
I didn’t need you I would tear your head from your scrawny shoulders.
Are your troops in place?
They fear me too much to be anything else.
Good. Come with me. I found something on the way here. Something important.
What is it?
You will see.
Hurry, then. Our plans will be ruined if you are missed in the city.
Here. By my chariot. Take a closer look. Open it.
That? That is worth risking everything for? I swear, if
this is a trick... Sound of a metal hinge opening, followed by a bizarre scrabbling and scratching sound. The sound gets louder.
&. Inside the Temple at Thebes.

FAYUM, a young priest is observing the stars and tutting. He is joined by ANTRANAK, head of the temple guards and Egypt's armies. They are friends but talk as if at war — baiting each other. If their tone wasn’t friendly, you'd think they loathed each other.
This is not good. Not good at all.
Still muttering and watching the night skies, Fayum? How are the omens? No, don’t tell me - they’re bad.
FAYUM The gods send signs in the skies that speak only of terrible things to come, Antranak.
Nonsense. We are safe inside Pharaoh's own palace with my troops on constant guard. Nothing can harm us here.
We shall see.
Sometimes I wonder what you priests are taught. Still, the Gods’ ways are not mine to question. I am only a soldier. Good night, Fayum. ANTRANAR’s footsteps echo into the distance.
(Softly) I fear we have very few good nights ahead of us.
3. TARDIS interior. The Fifth DOCTOR is giving PERI a tour of his ship. A door closes as they enter a corridor.
PERI And that’s the small library?
DOCTOR The big one’s up ahead.
I can’t believe there’s more. We’ve been wandering these corridors for hours.
I thought you wanted to know your way around.
I do, believe me, but I lost my bearings six corridors, three floors and two hours ago.
It just takes a little getting used to, that’s all. You’ll know your way about in no time.
So you really know what all these doors are?
Naturally. For instance, this is the main library.
He opens the door and we hear waves crashing on the shore.
PERI The books are going to get wet.
He shuts the door.
DOCTOR Of course, sometimes the TARDIS moves things about. Still, not to worry. A littie redecorating never hurt anybody.
PERI A little redecorating? You've got a lake in there.
Yes, I know. I much preferred it where it was. Where to next?
I don’t suppose you've got a restaurant stashed away here? My stomach thinks my throat’s been cut.
There should be a food machine around here somewhere.
I haven't used it much recently.
He ig interrupted by the sound of the TARDIS lurching and being buffeted and thrown about. He and PERI are thrown about. They thump into walis loudly.
Doctor?
Grab onto something.
More lurching and then it subsides.
I think it’s passed.
It feels so hot, suddenly...
Yes, that’s 2 bit worrying. Come on. This way. DOCTOR's footsteps hurry off along the corridor.
(Mutters) I'm fine thanks. How are you?
(Calling) Peri...
Slow down. I don’t want to get lost in this...
er footsteps follow the DOCTOR’s through a door. The Console Room ums.
How can the Console Room be here? We’ve gone down three flight of stairs and...”
Sssh.
Do...
Ssssh. Ah.
PERI From that ‘Ah!’ I take it I don’t have to ask if you know what happened.
We've materialised. The TARDIS has been reprogrammed.
By who? Is there somebody else on board?
I'm just checking. Oh. That can't be right. According to the
TARDIS, she was reprogrammed by me.
That’s impossible. We were stuck in the middle of this flying rabbit warren.
Yes, it does seem more than a little odd.
Where are we going now?
dust a short hop it seems. A few million miles to the side
and a couple of days back. Oh. We’re almost there.
One day soon, you're gonna have to teach me how these controls work.
(Not entirely convinced by the idea) Perhaps. Let’s see where we are first.
4. Ext. The Egyptian desert.
The wind blows, and is then interrupted by the TARDIS materialisation noise. The door opens and PERI hurries out of the TARDIS after the DOCTOR.
So where are we?
DOCTOR From the gravity and atmosphere (sniffs) I'd say Earth. No industrial by-products in the air? Definitely Barth. Egypt, roughly 1400BC.*
Oh, come on. Even you can’t tell all that from the air.
True, but the hieroglyphs on the wall of the house behind the TARDIS are a bit of a giveaway.
Smart guy. What do they say anyway?
They're prayers to ward off evil and protect the house.
A door rattles on its hinges in the wind.
Whoever lived here didn’t have much faith in their prayers, The place is abandoned. A few jars, some rope, bits of pottery, some clothes and an old wheel...
(Over Perf) Hmm. Very interesting. (Thoughtfuh Can you hear something?
Like what?
A young woman (17) is yelling and shouting for her horses to step. Her chariot is a runaway. She is ERIMEM. The horses snort and the chariot clatters.
Help me!
Like that.
Her chariot’s out of control.
There's another chariot. She’s being chased. All through we hear ERIMEM and her horses getting closer.
He's more than chasing her.
Behind the TARDIS. Quickly.
Arrows zing through the air and thud into the TARDIS. ERIMEM is still trying to stop her horses.
Stop! Slow down. Stop!
We have to do something.
I’m thinking.
Think faster. They’re almost on top of us.
He's can’t drive and use his bow accurately at the same time... Grab that rope over there. Tie one end round the TARDIS.
What are you going to do?
Take the other end to the far side of the breach in the wall and yank it tight after the first chariot is through.
This stuff’s so slippery. It’s coated with some kind of oil.
Steady. Steady.
Over here. This way. Peri, are you ready?
Nearly.
Hurry. She's almost through. Quickly.
The pounding of the horses is almost on top of them.
There. Done. She’s through. Pull it. Tight.
The sound of the rope going taught and then a shocked yell, followed by the sound of 4 man in armour hitting the ground hard.
We got him.
The fallen man (a scout named KISHIK) groans. ERIMEM is yelling for her horses to stop.
Stop. Slow now. Stop. Whoa.
No use. The horses thunder on.
Her horses have been scared out of their wits. She can’t control them. Keep an eye on our friend there.
What?
I don’t have time to argue. Someone has to stop those
horses. Tell your friend I borrowed his chariot for a few minutes.
The sound of the reins being flicked and the chariot moving off again.
Hya.
The fallen KISHIK groans and mumbles.
Wha...?
T hope this isn’t an antique.
The sound of a pottery jar being smashed over KISHIK ’s head. Another groan and he hits the dirt hard for the second time in under a minute.
Sorry.
8. Bxt. Desert.

Out in the desert, the DOCTOR's chariot is chasing ERIMEM’s. If we could see them the horses would be sweating up & foam as they charge across the desert. Their hooves are pounding loudly and they are brea’ heavily. There are two sets of chariot and horse sounds. The DOCTOR’s chariot is heavier and clatters more.
Hya. HYA!
WHOA. SLOW DOWN. STOP!
T'm almost there.
The DOCTOR’s chariot sounds are merging with ERIMEM's. They are now very close.
Help me.
Hang on.
Hurry.
You'll have to step across.
T can’t.
Your horses are too frightened to stop. There’s no
ouetnenive Cin almost there. Just a little closer.
In top of the horses’ snorting and pounding hooves, the sound of wheels touching and sparks flying. Both ERIMEM and the DOCTOR yelp. DOCTOR A little too close. Gently. Gently. Now. Step across.
I can't.
You have to. Hurry, I can't hold the chariots this close for long. Take my hand. Take it! Now jump. It’s just one step. Step now.
The sound of ERIMEM leaping over and landing on the DOCTOR's chariot.
Got you. It’s all right. I've got you. Whoa now. Whoa. The chariot pulls to a stop.
Are you hurt?
Stay away from me.
It’s all right. Pm not going to hurt you. Though I can’t say a same for the chap I borrowed this chariot from.* Where is he?
Back there with a friend of mine. Unconscious. Good. Get me away from here.
I don’t suppose you'd care to tell me why he was trying to kill you? You don’t know?
If I knew I wouldn’t ask, would I? You are a stranger here.
Weil, ’'ve been to Egypt before but I don’t think I’ve been recently,
Take me to Thebes.
You haven't answered my question.
When we are safe in Thebes, I will answer all your questions. Just get me there.
All right. Hold on. Hup. Giddup.
The horses pull the chariot away.
6. In the desert, by the TARDIS. The DOCTOR’s chariot pulls up by PERL
Doctor, 'm glad you're back.
Whoa.
See eens Another pot smashes and he hits the ground bard again. That's my last pot.
Loonoa You enjoyed that too much, young lady.
SRIME! I hoped he would be dead
T think that’s rather harsh, don’t you?
TRIBE] I owe him and his kind a hundred times worse.
‘You got her, then.
So it would seem.
So who is she? And why was this guy trying to mill her?
T thought he might have been a bandit but that's battle armour he's wearing.
Yes. 1 spotted that as well. And whoever this is, she’s too afraid to talk here. She's almost in shock. We'll take her to Thebes. She's sure she'll be safe there." And we might get. some answers.
What about him? Four of us on that chariot is going to be
cramped.
These war chariots were built for two passengers and a driver. Leave your sleeping friend there. He'll be all right in a minute or two, apart from a terrible headache.
Others of his kind are bound to be close by now. We must leave at once.
it
That might be a good idea. I've had more than enough excitement for one day.
PERI And we still don’t know what brought us here.
One crisis at a time, Peri. One crisis at a time. 7. The desert.
Another squadron of chariots pulls to a stop. In one is YANIS. He’s not best pleased at the DOCTOR’s rescue of ERIMEM. In the far distance we hear the DOCTOR'’s chariot clatter away.
Stop. Stop. We'll never catch them before they reach Thebes. Their archers would slaughter us as we approached. Damn you, Stranger. Where did you come from?
8. Thebes.
The chariot rattles and chunters towards Thebes.
Here we are, Peri. Thebes.
I didn’t expect it to be so huge.
Yes, impressive, isn’t it?
If Howard could see me now. He always complained that I didn't share his interest in history.
Where to?
ERIMEM The palace.
Are you sure? This is an enemy chariot, I don’t think they'll exactly welcome us with open arms.
That will not be a problem, Doctor.
Doctor... have you noticed the people...
.are all kneeling?
PERI And bowing. And generally grovelling.
Excuse me. I don’t think you told us exactly who you are.
No. I did not. Stand proud and firm. Show that nothing has happened to harm us.
We've got company.
So I see. Whoa there. Whoa.
The chariot halts. More chariots rattle to join them.
I don't like the look of those swords, Doctor.
ee I’m not too keen on the spears either. Best behaviour,
Mighty one. We sing praises to the Gods for your safe return.
Mighty one?
When ERIMEM speaks now there is a change in her. She is strong and firm. Regal.
Escort us to the palace, Antranak. We have a great deal to do but this is not the place to do it.
As you command, mighty Pharaoh.
aoe Pharaoh? CcTOR I must be getting old. I thought I knew the names of all or Egypt's pharaohs. a
Should I be bowing or curtsying or something?
Yes, but please refrain from doing so. The chariot is quite
small — and it would be very unseemly for a friend of Pharaoh to fall off in public.
Whatever you say.
I would wager, Doctor, that you did not expect anything like this when you first saw my chariot being chased.
Er, not really, no.
Mi But I think the unexpected is something you are familiar with. Am I right?
I was under the impression that divine Pharaoh is always right.
(Laughs) I’m yet to actually be crowned Doctor, but when
I have been, I think I would do well to avoid sparring in word games with you. Now smile and wave to the people. We have been victorious.
9. Yanis’s Camp.
is not best pleased. He's in a fouler than usual mood.

So. You are the spineless pig who let the whelp of a girl escape?® Do you have an explanation as to how the Egyptian pup escaped from a squadron of over a dozen chariots? Make your answer good, Kishik, or I will stake you in the sand and watch the buzzards feast on your eyes and innards.
It wasn’t my fault, sire. I plead for mercy.
Save your pleading, dung-beetle. I want answers. How did she escape?
She had a large escort. Six... No, ten chariots. We killed all the rest — we even got her driver.
YANIS. And still she escaped? Imbecile! Worse - coward!
No, Lord Yanis. She had help.
What help?
Arman with fair hair and strange clothing... And a violent
girl who repeatedly struck me even when I was unable to defend myself.
(Roaring - the pretence is gone) I know — I saw her. I saw ital. A girl should be no match for a man - or even you. Tell me about the man.
I barely saw him, sire. I only know that he knocked me from my chariot as if my magic.

Not magic, idiot - rope. But he handled the chariot like a true warrior. The brat’s horses were running as though they had demons at their tails but he took our chariot and caught them easily. I've never seen better.
Except for you, of course, mighty Yanis.
(Sneering at the grovelling, then thoughtful.) Of course. Even at speed he pulled the girl onto his chariot with one hand. My gut tells me he is a dangerous enemy.
Let me take a party into Thebes to kill him.
If I sent anyone to do that, it would be someone I could trust to follow orders. And you were ordered not to attack the Egyptian chariots until I arrived.
But they would have escaped if I had waited any longer. YaNIs What has happened is that now that unbedded whelp who calls herself Pharaoh knows that we are here and she knows that we will
attack sooner rather than later. I think I should slit you open and let the dogs feed. You’re worse than useless.® ;
No, great Yanis. Mercy, please. I have a wife and four children at home. Let me live. I will not fail you again. I am loyal. I have always been loyal to you.
YANIS And to my predecessor. As I remember, you helped me murder him. I will let you live, Kishik, but at a price.
Anything. I'll do anything...
I know you will. Come through here. My private shrine is in the back of this tent.
I am unworthy, lord.
Sound of them moving through.
It is dark. I can’t see.
Here, I'll bring a light.
What? Nol There fs an insect-like skittering sound - like thousands of insects milling about over each other.
NO! SAVE ME!
screams and then is quiet - only the insect skittering sound. YANIS At least now you may be useful.
10. Int. Brimem’s Suite at the Palace.
4A knock at the door.
Come.
Door opens and ANTRANAK enters.
Pharaoh.
You have news, Antranak?
Yes, Highness. I sent a chariot squadron to the area of the desert where you were attacked. The bodies of our men were recovered. They will be buried with honour and their souls will find rest.
Good. Meanwhile, I have ordered a banquet to thank the strangers who saved me today. I will need my friend there.
As you command. Majesty. (A little uncertainiy) You do these strangers a great honour with this banquet.
No more than they have earned.
True. But what do we know of them?
Only that they risked their lives to save mine without
knowing who or what I was. You don't trust them?
I don't know them. Majesty, but they arrived at a fortunate time for you. f
For which I am grateful.
As am I. Perhaps I have been a soldier too long, but good luck like this makes me suspicious. Especially when my Pharaoh's safety is in question.
(Kindly - this is a friend) We have all had enough bad fortune this year, Antranak. Let us celebrate what good luck we can.
I will be at the banquet as you wish. With your permission, I will go and prepare myself.
ERIMEM Of course.
Door clases behind ANTRANAK.
11. Int. Palace outside Erimem’s suite.
speaks to the soldiers on guard outside ERIMEM’s suite as he comes through the door.
Soldier. Double the guard on Great Pharaoh's chambers
Sir.
ANTRANAK And set others near the quarters of the pair who came into the city with Pharaoh, but don’t make it obvious. There’s no need for them to know we’re watching them.
12. The Palace at Thebes.
The DOCTOR is calling for PERI - a tad impatiently.
Peri, are you ready yet?
TP be out in a minute.
Do try to hurry. It’s considered bad form to keep the ruler of the known world waiting in her own palace.
Okay, okay. Here I come, ready or not. Well? What do you think?
You've been busy.”
Not me. I’ve had half a dozen servants helping me bathe, get this dress on, put this stuff on my eyes...
Kohl. It’s used to make the sloe-eye shape.
PERI At least you didn’t have servants trying to shave your head.
Well, it is their custom for people to have bald heads and
wear wigs. Much cooler in the heat, apparently.
Can we see the pyramids from here? I’ve always wanted to see them. And the Sphinx.
I’m afraid not. Thebes is quite a way from Giza. If we were in the Royal Palace at Memphis it would be a different story. Shall we?
Is something wrong? You look a bit, I don’t know - edgy.
Just hoping my memory's playing up, that’s all. I can name every Pharaoh Egypt ever had and I'm certain there was never a Pharaoh Erimem.
She's due to be crowned in a few weeks. You must be wrong. Maybe you just forgot her.
Female pharaohs were a rarity, Peri. I’m not likely to forget one. Hatchepsut... Smenkhare... No. Something must happen to stop Erimem being crowned.
PERI And now we have to go and have a banquet with her,
knowing that she never gets to be Pharaoh? You really know how to kill
an evening, Doctor.
13. Int. Palace at Thebes.
There are the sounds of a crowd gathering. Low talking and muted music.
You look worried, Antranak. Of course, you always look ‘worried.
I'm in no mood for your humour today, Fayum.
I fear your mood is about to get worse.
They are joined by HOREMSHEP.
Greetings to you both.
What do you want, Horemshep?
Does the Priest of Horus need a reason for speaking to the head of the palace guard? ;
You never do anything without a reason. What is it this time?
Nothing. What do you know of the strangers Pharaoh honours with this banquet?
Only what my Pharaoh tells me. That is enough — for anyone. Even the chief of priests.
HOREMSHEP Of course. But still, I am curious.
Then question Pharaoh and leave me be.
Surely you're not jealous of Pharaoh’s new friends, Antranak? She has never honoured you with a banquet. But then, you haven't saved her life either.
1 warn you, priest...
(Butting in) If you are so interested in Pharaoh’s guests, Horemshep, why not ask them? They have just arrived.
A little fanfare heralds the entrance of PERI and the DOCTOR.
Perhaps later. Gentiemen.
HOREMSHEP’s footsteps head away.
Why does he constantly bait you, Antranak?
Because I have almost as much influence in the palace as he does and that eats away at him. But I should know better than to rise to his bait. And now I have duties to perform.
FAYUM OF course.
13a. Int. Palace. The rumblings of the large gathering. Lots of chatter. Muted
conversations as if we're moving through the great hall until we get to the DOCTOR and PERI.
Is this party all for us, Doctor?
Music is played — a fanfare
I think we're on.
(Grandly) The great and mighty queen, daughter of the stars. Pharaoh in the eyes of the Gods and soon to be crowned, all bow to Erimemushinteperem, divine and eternal, the living god.
(Quietly) Peri, kneel.
(Muttering - struggling a bit) I'd like to see you kneel wearing a dress this tight.
Ssh.
Rise and approach, Doctor. And you, Peri.
Slight delay while the footsteps of the DOCTOR and PERI approach the throne.
ERIMEM The Doctor and Peri have done great service to your Pharaoh and to Egypt. As thanks, Doctor, I give you this cartouche
bearing my divine name. It marks you as friend of Pharaoh and under my divine protection.
You do us great honour, mighty Pharaoh.
Now let the banquet begin. A walloping great gong.
You will sit by Pharaoh, Doctor. poem Thank you. Absolutely, your Majesty.
speaks to FAYUM, renewing their banter.
Nice speech, Antranak.
This is a strange day, Fayum. An outsider sitting at Pharaob's right hand.
FayumM Pharaoh makes her own decisions. ANTRANAK And some do not like them? PAYUM To say that would be to admit treason. Everyone knows
that divine Pharaoh is infallible.
Not everyone shares your opinion. I know of the split in the council of priests.
PAYuM Officially, there is no split - only a... debate.
You will have to learn to lie better than that if you want to prosper at court.
Back at the top table, PERI is obviously having a bit of a look round.
Doctor, what’s with the bug motif around the hall? DOCTOR The Scarab Beetle. Some of the priests think the beetle is sacred.
It’s Just like being at home — Mom worshipped Paul McCartney. I wish I'd brought a camera.
DOCTOE And how would you explain it to the developer?
Never been to a toga party?
Well, I was at a bash Nero threw once.
Music starts up. Obviously music for the dancing girls.
i" The entertainment.
Dancers? Oh. They’re topless! DoeTOR Well. yes I suppose they are. It’s the custom. Just ignore them if it bothers you.
Easy for you to say. You're not being letched at by that black toothed priest over there. If he asks me to dance I'll punch him.
You'll do no such thing That's the Priest of the Temple of Horus. He's chief of the council of priests.-~
Just joking. Those other topless girls — are they the next dancers?
Ab... well no. Actually. they're a different kind of entertainment.
Singers? (Dawn of realisation) You dont mean...
hookers? These people need a cold shower.
E E i ; 5 g
You must try the roast boar. Tt is absohitely exceRent. Why not? (Claps hands to SLAVE) Bring boar for my guest.**
Is now a good time to remind you that I'm a vegetarian?
(Quietly) It would be a huge Ingult to refuse Pharaoh's recommendation. Just push it round your plate. he
Sounds of a servant dishing up from a platter. His accent is not local.
You want more boar, lady?
No thanks. I don’t want to pig out. That’s not meant to be a bad pig joke. Sorry.
(Confused) Lady?
Never mind.
Lord?
I don’t mind if I do. Thank you.
Sound of the slave spilling food as he serves it up. The plate scraping and the DOCTOR shifting quickly.
Careful.
I am sorry, Lord.
Our apologies, Doctor.
It’s all right. No harm done.
(Quietly) The waiter’s not very good, is he?
No. His clothes don’t quite fit him either, come to that.
No more boar for me.
Scraping on the plate.
I said...
Sound of a heavy plate being thrown aside.
Death to Erimem!
No!
Doctor!
Yells and noises of confusion and struggle, including a cry of pain from the DOCTOR.
You have saved me again, Doctor.
You're bleeding.
(Obviously in a bit of pain) It’s nothing much. Just a flesh
wound, really. The knife only grazed my hand.
The SLAVE laughs.
Tell me what is so funny, before you die.
(Struggling — obviously being choked) Then I will not die alone. The dagger was coated with poison. He has only minutes to live.
Sound of someone keeling over, sending plates spilling noisily to the floor.
Doctor! um
END OF PART ONE

Okay, I've just read through your notes a couple of times. For the most part I agree with your points. Some of the dialogue is ghastly and cumbersome - getting the point over but without any subtlety. I don’t remember them being so duff when I wrote the thing, but in hindsight, some of the dialogue is a bit, well, crap (and I'm probably being kind to myself there). That can be fixed.

If you think the Doctor's dialogue has strayed from Peter Davison to Colin Baker, then that’s a bad mistake I'll need to fix. I thought the Fifth Doctor was gutsier in Peter Davison's last year (admittedly in The Caves of Androzani it was because he knew he was going to peg out), but all through that year I thought he was a stronger, firmer character and I tried to push him that way. But if I've cocked it up, it needs to be fixed.

Peri’s dialogue can be fixed as well. Less cocky, more intelligent? Less cheap gags? Stronger and pushing the action more. How about if she pushes for the investigation of the Palace of Concubines, and cajoles Erimem into joining her? With a bit of tweaking, the scenes in the tunnels and Palace of Concubines could change emphasis so that Peri is more of the driving force. When she gets taken as a hostage in Part Three, instead of having Peri turfed off the chariot, if she broke free and jumped she'd be freeing herself without need for rescue.

You mentioned that you wanted a less linear plot and some kind of interaction between Peri and Antranak. Rather than have him develop a crush on her, how about if he’s wary of both Peri and the Doctor? He's been Erimem’s adviser thus far, and now she's got new favourites. He’s not jealous of Erimem (who's 17, by the way) showing them favour, but they arrived just at the right time - and that's a bit lucky for his liking. He doesn’t know anything about these people, which makes him uncomfortable. So he could be wary of Peri, try to get some answers from her about who she is, where she and the Doctor came from, etc. It would all be to protect Erimem but it would give a bit of edge to him from the listener’s point of view - he’s got a problem with Peri,so maybe he’s a bit iffy. This would give Peri the chance to stand up to Antranak when he’s niggling at her. I'd also like to add a scene where the Charioteer (the Scout) is being interrogated (tortured). Peri thinks it’s barbaric (inwardly, Erimem probably agrees) but Antranak thinks Peri’s objections to torture are a bit shady. Why doesn't she want this cnemy to be forced to tell what he knows? And when the Scout escapes, he suspects Peri even more. (Obviously it’s the Horus character who lets the Scout go.) If Anteanak’s character is that wee bit greyer and edgier, when he’s accused of the killings, for a second, we might think, yeah, it’s possible he did it to protect Erimem.The extra plotline should make scene changes easier, particularly in Parts Two and Three.

As for Horus, the chief priests of each god's temple took the name of that god and. were usually addressed by the god’s name. The priests still retained their own names (even if they rarely used them) so there's no hassle with calling the character by his own name Chow does Horemshep sound?) - all that would need would be an early mention of him being the High Priest of Horus, and leader of the Council of Priests. d did think about calling him Anubis, but again, that’s a god's name, which might make folk think of the Osirians, and besides, everyone associates Anubis with death, so it'll be a bit of a giveaway that he’s the bad guy.) A more modern idea is that Smenkhare is actually Atenakhen’s wife, Nefertiti. At first her name was just Nerfertiti, then she changed it to Nefer-Nefer-Nuahu-Nefertiti (fit that on a cheque). According to myths recounted in various Graham Hancock and Robert Bauval type books. the tunnel leads to a giant chamber between the front paws of the Sphinx, and also branches off into the pyramids. Whether it does or not. I've no idea, but ] thought it was worth using the myth. TARDIS: It wouldn't be common for women of this era to read but it wouldn't be unheard of either. A lot would depend on where the women came from. The nature of the Pharaoh involved comes into it a lot as well. If Pharach wanted to keep his women uneducated, well. that was that really. TARDIS: By the way CWARNING - high boredom factor ahead), stating that Smenkhare was female is taking sides in a contentious debate amongst Egyptian scholars. Traditionalists go with the idea that Smenkhare was a noble who succeeded Atenakhen and that’s that, so there and yah-boo-sucks. A more modern idea is that Smenkhare is actually Atenakhen’s wife, Nefertiti. At first her name was just Nerfertiti, then she changed it to Nefer-Nefer-Nuahu-Nefertiti (fit that on a cheque). She disappeared totally from history at the exact time that the co-ruler, joint Pharaoh (and lover if we go by the smutty carvings) of Atenakhen appeared. This co-ruler was Smenkhare-Nefer-Nefer-Nuahu. So, one side says it’s the same person. The other side shouts ‘bollocks’ and the intellectual debate contuinues. It’s not really a big thing - but I reckoned that Doctor Who would always come down backing the controversial side of an argument like this one.
